diseases.name: Diabetes
symptoms: Tingling or numbness in hands and feet
precautions: Maintain a healthy and balanced diet
Exercise regularly to control blood sugar levels
Monitor blood sugar levels frequently
Take prescribed medications or insulin as directed
Avoid excessive sugar and carbohydrate intake
Stay hydrated
Manage stress effectively
Get regular medical checkups
diseases.description: Diabetes is a chronic condition that affects how the body processes blood sugar (glucose). There are two main types: Type 1 (autoimmune condition where the body doesn't produce insulin) and Type 2 (body becomes resistant to insulin). Proper management through diet, exercise, and medication is essential to prevent complications such as heart disease, kidney damage, and nerve problems.
medicines: Metformin (for Type 2 diabetes)
Insulin therapy (for Type 1 and severe Type 2 diabetes)
Sulfonylureas (such as Glipizide, Glyburide)
DPP-4 inhibitors (such as Sitagliptin)
SGLT2 inhibitors (such as Empagliflozin, Canagliflozin)
GLP-1 receptor agonists (such as Liraglutide, Semaglutide)
Alpha-glucosidase inhibitors (such as Acarbose)

diseases.name: Hypertension
symptoms: Often no symptoms in early stages
precautions: Maintain a low-sodium and heart-healthy diet
Exercise regularly (at least 30 minutes a day)
Monitor blood pressure regularly
Manage stress through relaxation techniques
Avoid smoking and excessive alcohol consumption
Maintain a healthy weight
Take prescribed medications as directed
Get regular medical checkups
diseases.description: Hypertension, or high blood pressure, occurs when the force of blood against the artery walls is consistently too high. It can lead to serious complications such as heart disease, stroke, kidney failure, and vision loss. Lifestyle changes and medication can help manage the condition effectively.
medicines: ACE inhibitors (such as Lisinopril, Enalapril)
Beta-blockers (such as Metoprolol, Atenolol)
Calcium channel blockers (such as Amlodipine, Diltiazem)
Diuretics (such as Hydrochlorothiazide, Furosemide)
Angiotensin II receptor blockers (such as Losartan, Valsartan)
Alpha-blockers (such as Doxazosin, Prazosin)
Combination medications (for severe cases)

diseases.name: Influenza
symptoms: Nausea or vomiting (more common in children)
precautions: Get an annual flu vaccine
Wash hands frequently with soap and water
Avoid close contact with infected individuals
Cover mouth and nose when sneezing or coughing
Stay hydrated and eat a balanced diet
Rest and avoid strenuous activities if feeling unwell
Disinfect frequently touched surfaces
Wear a mask in crowded places during flu season
diseases.description: Influenza, commonly known as the flu, is a contagious respiratory illness caused by influenza viruses. It spreads through respiratory droplets when an infected person coughs or sneezes. Symptoms range from mild to severe, and complications can include pneumonia, bronchitis, and worsening of chronic medical conditions.
medicines: Oseltamivir (Tamiflu) – antiviral medication
Zanamivir (Relenza) – antiviral medication
Baloxavir marboxil (Xofluza) – antiviral medication
Paracetamol (for fever and pain relief)
Ibuprofen (for pain and inflammation)
Decongestants (for nasal congestion)
Cough suppressants (for persistent cough)

diseases.name: Asthma
symptoms: Coughing, especially at night or early morning
Fatigue due to poor sleep from breathing difficulties
precautions: Avoid exposure to allergens and pollutants
Use prescribed inhalers as directed
Maintain indoor air quality with air purifiers
Exercise regularly but avoid overexertion
Practice breathing exercises and stress management
Stay up to date with flu and pneumonia vaccines
Avoid smoking and secondhand smoke
Follow an asthma action plan provided by a doctor
diseases.description: Asthma is a chronic respiratory condition that causes inflammation and narrowing of the airways, leading to difficulty in breathing. It can be triggered by allergens, cold air, exercise, or respiratory infections. Proper management with medication and lifestyle adjustments is essential to prevent asthma attacks.
medicines: Albuterol (short-acting bronchodilator for quick relief)
Salmeterol (long-acting bronchodilator)
Fluticasone (inhaled corticosteroid)
Budesonide (inhaled corticosteroid)
Montelukast (leukotriene receptor antagonist)
Theophylline (oral medication for airway relaxation)
Omalizumab (for severe allergic asthma)

diseases.name: Tuberculosis
symptoms: Persistent cough lasting more than three weeks
precautions: Get vaccinated with the BCG vaccine
Cover mouth and nose while coughing or sneezing
Ensure proper ventilation in living spaces
Avoid close contact with infected individuals
Complete the full course of TB medication as prescribed
Maintain good hygiene and sanitation
Improve immunity through a healthy diet and lifestyle
diseases.description: Tuberculosis (TB) is a contagious bacterial infection caused by *Mycobacterium tuberculosis*. It primarily affects the lungs but can also spread to other organs. TB spreads through airborne droplets when an infected person coughs or sneezes. If untreated, it can be life-threatening, but it is curable with proper medication.
medicines: Isoniazid (INH) – first-line antibiotic
Rifampin (RIF) – first-line antibiotic
Ethambutol (EMB) – used in combination therapy
Pyrazinamide (PZA) – for initial treatment phase
Streptomycin – for drug-resistant TB cases
Bedaquiline – for multidrug-resistant TB
Delamanid – for extensively drug-resistant TB

diseases.name: Malaria
precautions: Use mosquito nets while sleeping
Apply insect repellent containing DEET
Wear long-sleeved clothing in mosquito-prone areas
Eliminate stagnant water to prevent mosquito breeding
Take antimalarial medication before traveling to endemic areas
Stay in air-conditioned or screened rooms
Seek medical attention if symptoms appear after travel
diseases.description: Malaria is a life-threatening disease caused by *Plasmodium* parasites, which are transmitted through the bites of infected Anopheles mosquitoes. It is prevalent in tropical and subtropical regions. If left untreated, malaria can lead to severe complications such as organ failure and death.
medicines: Chloroquine (for non-resistant strains)
Artemisinin-based combination therapies (ACTs)
Quinine sulfate (for severe cases)
Mefloquine (for prevention and treatment)
Primaquine (to prevent relapse of *P. vivax* and *P. ovale*)
Doxycycline (as a preventive measure)
Atovaquone-proguanil (for treatment and prevention)

diseases.name: Dengue
symptoms: Mild bleeding (nosebleeds, gum bleeding, or easy bruising)
precautions: Use mosquito repellents and wear protective clothing
Avoid mosquito breeding by keeping surroundings clean
Use mosquito nets while sleeping
Stay hydrated to prevent complications
Seek medical attention if symptoms worsen
Avoid taking aspirin or ibuprofen without medical advice
diseases.description: Dengue is a viral infection transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes. It causes flu-like symptoms and, in severe cases, can lead to dengue hemorrhagic fever or dengue shock syndrome, which can be life-threatening. Early diagnosis and proper hydration are crucial for recovery.
medicines: Paracetamol (to reduce fever and pain)
Intravenous fluids (for severe cases)
Electrolyte solutions (to prevent dehydration)
Blood transfusion (in case of severe bleeding)
Rest and proper hydration

diseases.name: covid 19
precautions: Wear a mask in crowded places
Maintain social distancing
Wash hands frequently with soap and water
Use hand sanitizer when soap is not available
Get vaccinated and stay up to date with booster shots
Avoid touching face, eyes, nose, and mouth
Isolate if experiencing symptoms or tested positive
Improve ventilation in indoor spaces
diseases.description: COVID-19 is a respiratory illness caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus. It spreads through respiratory droplets from infected individuals. While mild in some cases, it can lead to severe pneumonia, organ failure, and death, especially in older adults or those with underlying health conditions.
medicines: Paracetamol (for fever and pain relief)
Antiviral drugs (such as Paxlovid, Molnupiravir, or Remdesivir)
Corticosteroids (such as Dexamethasone for severe cases)
Oxygen therapy (for patients with breathing difficulties)
Monoclonal antibodies (for high-risk patients)
IV fluids (for hydration in severe cases)

diseases.name: Ebola
precautions: Avoid contact with infected persons
Wear protective clothing
Practice good hygiene
Seek medical care
diseases.description: A severe and often fatal viral disease.
medicines: Supportive therapy
IV fluids
Experimental antivirals
Blood transfusions

diseases.name: Hepatitis B
symptoms: Swelling in the legs (in severe cases)
Liver damage or cirrhosis (in chronic cases)
precautions: Get vaccinated against Hepatitis B
Avoid sharing needles, razors, or toothbrushes
Practice safe sex (use protection)
Ensure blood products are screened before transfusion
Maintain proper hygiene and sanitation
Avoid excessive alcohol consumption to protect the liver
Get regular liver function tests if at risk
diseases.description: Hepatitis B is a viral infection that affects the liver, caused by the Hepatitis B virus (HBV). It spreads through contact with infected blood, bodily fluids, or from mother to child during birth. While some cases are acute and resolve on their own, chronic infections can lead to severe liver damage, cirrhosis, or liver cancer.
medicines: Entecavir (for chronic Hepatitis B)
Tenofovir (to reduce viral load)
Lamivudine (for antiviral treatment)
Adefovir (for long-term management)
Interferon-alpha (to boost immune response)
Hepatitis B Immunoglobulin (for post-exposure prophylaxis)

diseases.name: Pneumonia
symptoms: Chest pain when breathing or coughing
Bluish lips or fingernails (in severe cases)
precautions: Get vaccinated (Pneumococcal and flu vaccines)
Wash hands frequently with soap and water
Avoid smoking to protect lung health
Maintain a strong immune system with a healthy diet
Practice proper respiratory hygiene (cover mouth when coughing)
Avoid close contact with sick individuals
Seek early treatment for respiratory infections
diseases.description: Pneumonia is a lung infection caused by bacteria, viruses, or fungi. It leads to inflammation in the air sacs (alveoli), which may fill with fluid or pus, making breathing difficult. It can range from mild to life-threatening, particularly in infants, elderly individuals, and people with weakened immune systems.
medicines: Amoxicillin (for bacterial pneumonia)
Azithromycin (for atypical pneumonia)
Ceftriaxone (for severe bacterial pneumonia)
Levofloxacin (for bacterial pneumonia)
Oseltamivir (for viral pneumonia caused by influenza)
Antifungal medications (for fungal pneumonia)
Oxygen therapy (for severe cases with breathing difficulty)

diseases.name: Chickenpox
symptoms: Itchy red rash that turns into fluid-filled blisters
Blisters that scab over after a few days
precautions: Get vaccinated (Varicella vaccine)
Avoid close contact with infected individuals
Wash hands frequently
Do not scratch blisters to prevent infection
Stay isolated until blisters have scabbed over
Keep fingernails short and clean
Wear loose, comfortable clothing to reduce irritation
diseases.description: Chickenpox is a highly contagious viral infection caused by the varicella-zoster virus. It is characterized by an itchy rash with fluid-filled blisters. The disease is common in children but can be more severe in adults. A vaccine is available to prevent infection.
medicines: Acetaminophen (to reduce fever and pain)
Antihistamines (to relieve itching)
Calamine lotion (to soothe skin irritation)
Acyclovir (for severe cases or immunocompromised patients)
Hydration and rest to support recovery

diseases.name: Typhoid Fever
precautions: Get vaccinated against typhoid fever
Drink only purified or boiled water
Practice proper hand hygiene
Avoid raw or undercooked food
Wash fruits and vegetables thoroughly before eating
Avoid street food in endemic areas
Take antibiotics only as prescribed by a doctor
diseases.description: Typhoid fever is a bacterial infection caused by *Salmonella Typhi*. It spreads through contaminated food and water, particularly in regions with poor sanitation. If left untreated, typhoid can lead to severe complications such as intestinal perforation and organ failure. Early diagnosis and antibiotic treatment are essential for recovery.
medicines: Ciprofloxacin (for non-resistant strains)
Azithromycin (for mild to moderate cases)
Ceftriaxone (for severe or drug-resistant cases)
Paracetamol (for fever and pain management)
Oral rehydration salts (to prevent dehydration)

diseases.name: Rabies
precautions: Get vaccinated against rabies if at risk
Avoid contact with stray or wild animals
Immediately clean any animal bite wound with soap and water
Seek medical attention for any animal bite or scratch
Ensure pets are vaccinated against rabies
Report stray or aggressive animals to local authorities
Use protective gear when handling animals in high-risk areas
diseases.description: Rabies is a deadly viral infection that affects the central nervous system. It is transmitted through the saliva of infected animals, usually via bites or scratches. Once symptoms appear, rabies is almost always fatal. However, timely vaccination after exposure can prevent the disease.
medicines: Rabies vaccine (post-exposure prophylaxis)
Rabies immunoglobulin (for immediate neutralization of the virus)
Supportive care (for symptom management in late-stage cases)

diseases.name: Measles
precautions: Get vaccinated
Avoid infected individuals
Wash hands frequently
Isolate infected persons
diseases.description: A highly contagious viral disease.
medicines: Vitamin A
Acetaminophen
Supportive care

diseases.name: Cholera
precautions: Maintain hygiene
Vaccinate if available
Avoid infected individuals
Seek medical attention
diseases.description: Cholera is a disease that can have serious health effects.
medicines: Prescribed antibiotics
Pain relievers
Supportive care
Anti-inflammatory drugs

diseases.name: hiv
symptoms: Memory loss or neurological complications (in later stages)
precautions: Practice safe sex (use condoms)
Avoid sharing needles or syringes
Get tested regularly for HIV
Ensure blood transfusions use screened blood
Take pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) if at high risk
Avoid contact with infected body fluids
Pregnant HIV-positive women should take antiretroviral therapy (ART) to prevent mother-to-child transmission
diseases.description: HIV (Human Immunodeficiency Virus) is a virus that attacks the immune system, making the body more vulnerable to infections and diseases. If left untreated, it can progress to AIDS (Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome), a life-threatening condition. While there is no cure, HIV can be managed with antiretroviral therapy (ART), allowing patients to lead long and healthy lives.
medicines: Tenofovir (part of ART therapy)
Emtricitabine (helps suppress the virus)
Efavirenz (reduces viral load)
Dolutegravir (integrase inhibitor for viral suppression)
Ritonavir (protease inhibitor to boost ART effectiveness)
Lamivudine (commonly used in HIV treatment)
Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) for high-risk individuals

diseases.name: Lyme Disease
precautions: Maintain hygiene
Vaccinate if available
Avoid infected individuals
Seek medical attention
diseases.description: Lyme Disease is a disease that can have serious health effects.
medicines: Prescribed antibiotics
Pain relievers
Supportive care
Anti-inflammatory drugs

diseases.name: Meningitis
precautions: Maintain hygiene
Vaccinate if available
Avoid infected individuals
Seek medical attention
diseases.description: Meningitis is a disease that can have serious health effects.
medicines: Prescribed antibiotics
Pain relievers
Supportive care
Anti-inflammatory drugs

diseases.name: Polio
symptoms: Stiffness in the neck and back
Joint pain or deformities (in post-polio syndrome)
precautions: Get vaccinated with the polio vaccine (OPV/IPV)
Ensure good hygiene and sanitation
Drink clean, purified water
Wash hands frequently with soap
Avoid close contact with infected individuals
Properly dispose of human waste
Strengthen the immune system with a healthy diet and exercise
diseases.description: Polio (poliomyelitis) is a highly contagious viral disease caused by the poliovirus. It primarily affects children under five years old and can lead to permanent paralysis or even death in severe cases. Polio spreads through contaminated food, water, and person-to-person contact. Vaccination is the most effective way to prevent polio.
medicines: There is no cure for polio, only supportive treatment
Pain relievers (to reduce muscle pain and fever)
Physical therapy (to prevent deformities and improve mobility)
Ventilator support (for severe cases affecting breathing)
Orthopedic devices (such as braces and mobility aids)

diseases.name: Psoriasis
symptoms: Red patches of skin covered with thick, silvery scales
Dry, cracked skin that may bleed
Swollen and stiff joints (in psoriatic arthritis)
Scaly patches on the scalp, elbows, knees, and lower back
precautions: Keep skin moisturized to prevent dryness and irritation
Avoid triggers such as stress, smoking, and alcohol
Maintain a healthy diet and weight
Protect skin from injuries and infections
Limit exposure to cold, dry weather
Use mild soaps and avoid harsh skin products
Follow prescribed treatment plans from a dermatologist
diseases.description: Psoriasis is a chronic autoimmune disease that causes rapid skin cell turnover, leading to scaling, inflammation, and redness. It is not contagious but can be triggered by stress, infections, or environmental factors. Psoriasis may also lead to psoriatic arthritis, affecting the joints.
medicines: Topical corticosteroids (to reduce inflammation and scaling)
Vitamin D analogs (such as Calcipotriol to slow skin cell growth)
Coal tar treatments (for mild to moderate cases)
Methotrexate (for severe psoriasis and psoriatic arthritis)
Biologic drugs (such as Adalimumab, Infliximab for immune system regulation)
Phototherapy (UV light therapy to reduce symptoms)

diseases.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
precautions: Maintain hygiene
Vaccinate if available
Avoid infected individuals
Seek medical attention
diseases.description: Rheumatoid Arthritis is a disease that can have serious health effects.
medicines: Prescribed antibiotics
Pain relievers
Supportive care
Anti-inflammatory drugs

precautions: Maintain hygiene
Vaccinate if available

diseases.description: Salmonella is a disease that can have serious health effects.
medicines: Prescribed antibiotics
Pain relievers

diseases.name: Scabies
symptoms: Thin, irregular burrow tracks on the skin
Commonly affected areas: between fingers, wrists, elbows, armpits, waist, and genitals
precautions: Avoid close physical contact with infected individuals
Wash bedding, clothing, and towels in hot water
Vacuum furniture and carpets regularly
Do not share personal items such as clothes or towels
Apply prescribed medication properly to all affected areas
Complete the full course of treatment to prevent reinfection
Isolate infected individuals until treatment is completed
diseases.description: Scabies is a highly contagious skin infestation caused by the *Sarcoptes scabiei* mite. It spreads through direct skin-to-skin contact and sometimes through infested clothing or bedding. The mites burrow into the skin, causing intense itching and irritation. Effective treatment is available to eliminate the mites and manage symptoms.
medicines: Permethrin cream (topical treatment to kill mites)
Ivermectin (oral medication for severe cases or outbreaks)
Crotamiton (alternative topical treatment)
Antihistamines (to relieve itching)
Hydrocortisone cream (to reduce inflammation and irritation)
Benzyl benzoate (used in some cases to kill mites)

diseases.name: Shingles
precautions: Maintain hygiene
Vaccinate if available
Avoid infected individuals
Seek medical attention
diseases.description: Shingles is a disease that can have serious health effects.
medicines: Prescribed antibiotics
Pain relievers
Supportive care
Anti-inflammatory drugs

diseases.name: Cancer
symptoms: Lump or swelling in any part of the body
Changes in skin (new mole, darkened skin, yellowing)
Chronic pain in bones or joints
precautions: Avoid smoking and excessive alcohol consumption
Maintain a healthy diet rich in fruits and vegetables
Exercise regularly and maintain a healthy weight
Protect skin from excessive sun exposure (use sunscreen, wear protective clothing)
Get regular screenings and medical checkups
Avoid exposure to harmful chemicals and radiation
Get vaccinated for cancer-related viruses (HPV, Hepatitis B)
diseases.description: Cancer is a group of diseases characterized by the uncontrolled growth and spread of abnormal cells. If not controlled, it can result in tumors, organ damage, and death. There are many types of cancer, such as lung cancer, breast cancer, prostate cancer, and leukemia. Early detection through screenings and a healthy lifestyle can help in prevention and management.
medicines: Paclitaxel
Doxorubicin
Cisplatin
Imatinib
Trastuzumab
Pembrolizumab
Nivolumab
Tamoxifen
Anastrozole

diseases.name: Lung Cancer
precautions: Avoid smoking and exposure to tobacco smoke
Reduce exposure to pollutants and chemicals
Eat a healthy diet rich in fruits and vegetables
Exercise regularly
Get regular health checkups and screenings
Avoid exposure to asbestos and radon gas
Use protective equipment if working in hazardous environments
diseases.description: Lung cancer is a type of cancer that starts in the lungs. It is commonly associated with smoking but can also occur due to exposure to pollutants, chemicals, and genetic factors. Symptoms may not appear in early stages, making regular screenings important for early detection.
medicines: Cisplatin
Carboplatin
Erlotinib
Gefitinib
Pembrolizumab
Nivolumab
Paclitaxel
Docetaxel

diseases.name: Thyroid Disease
precautions: Maintain a balanced diet rich in iodine
Avoid excessive consumption of processed foods
Get regular thyroid function tests
Exercise regularly to maintain metabolism
Manage stress effectively
Avoid excessive consumption of soy-based products
Follow prescribed medication regimen if diagnosed
diseases.description: Thyroid disease refers to a range of disorders affecting the thyroid gland, including hypothyroidism, hyperthyroidism, goiter, and thyroid cancer. The thyroid plays a critical role in regulating metabolism, energy levels, and overall bodily functions.
medicines: Levothyroxine
Methimazole
Propylthiouracil
Liothyronine
Radioactive iodine therapy
Beta-blockers (for symptom control)
Thyroid hormone replacement therapy

diseases.name: Thyroid Cancer
symptoms: Lump or swelling in the neck
Pain in the throat or neck
Swollen lymph nodes in the neck
Persistent cough not related to a cold
precautions: Get regular thyroid checkups, especially if there is a family history
Avoid exposure to excessive radiation
Maintain a diet rich in iodine (as per doctor's advice)
Monitor any unusual lumps or swelling in the neck
Quit smoking and avoid alcohol consumption
Follow proper medication and treatment plans if diagnosed
Consider genetic testing if at high risk
diseases.description: Thyroid cancer occurs when abnormal cells grow uncontrollably in the thyroid gland. It is usually detected as a lump or swelling in the neck and can be treated successfully if diagnosed early. There are different types, including papillary, follicular, medullary, and anaplastic thyroid cancer.
medicines: Levothyroxine (to replace thyroid hormones after treatment)
Radioactive iodine therapy
Sorafenib (targeted therapy)
Lenvatinib (targeted therapy)
Doxorubicin (for advanced cases)
Surgery (thyroidectomy)
External beam radiation therapy

diseases.name: Heart Attack
symptoms: Pain in the arms, neck, jaw, or back
precautions: Maintain a healthy diet low in saturated fats and cholesterol
Exercise regularly to improve heart health
Avoid smoking and excessive alcohol consumption
Control high blood pressure, diabetes, and cholesterol levels
Manage stress effectively
Maintain a healthy weight
Take prescribed medications as directed
diseases.description: A heart attack occurs when the blood flow to a part of the heart is blocked, usually by a clot. This causes damage to the heart muscle and can be life-threatening if not treated promptly. Symptoms can vary, and immediate medical attention is required.
medicines: Aspirin (to prevent blood clotting)
Nitroglycerin (to relieve chest pain)
Clopidogrel (blood thinner)
Beta-blockers (to reduce heart workload)
Statins (to lower cholesterol)
ACE inhibitors (to manage blood pressure)
Thrombolytics (to dissolve blood clots)

diseases.name: Anxiety
precautions: Practice deep breathing and relaxation techniques
Engage in regular physical exercise
Limit caffeine and alcohol intake
Maintain a healthy and balanced diet
Ensure proper sleep hygiene
Avoid stressful situations when possible
Seek social support from friends and family
Practice mindfulness and meditation
Consider professional counseling or therapy if needed
diseases.description: Anxiety is a mental health disorder characterized by persistent and excessive worry or fear. It can interfere with daily life and manifest with physical symptoms such as rapid heartbeat, sweating, and difficulty breathing. Anxiety can be managed through lifestyle changes, therapy, and medication when necessary.
medicines: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) such as Sertraline, Fluoxetine
Benzodiazepines such as Alprazolam, Lorazepam (short-term use only)
Beta-blockers such as Propranolol (for physical symptoms like rapid heartbeat)
Buspirone (for generalized anxiety disorder)
Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) as a non-medication approach
Herbal supplements such as Ashwagandha or Chamomile (consult a doctor before use)

diseases.name: Allergies
symptoms: Swelling of the face, lips, or throat
Anaphylaxis (severe allergic reaction requiring immediate medical attention)
precautions: Avoid known allergens (pollen, dust, pet dander, certain foods, etc.)
Use air purifiers to reduce indoor allergens
Wear masks in high-pollen environments
Wash hands and face after outdoor activities
Use hypoallergenic bedding and clean regularly
Carry an epinephrine auto-injector (if prescribed for severe allergies)
Take antihistamines before exposure to known allergens
Check food labels for allergenic ingredients
diseases.description: Allergies occur when the immune system overreacts to harmless substances such as pollen, dust mites, pet dander, or certain foods. Symptoms range from mild (sneezing, itching) to severe (anaphylaxis). Managing allergies involves avoiding triggers, taking medications, and, in severe cases, seeking medical treatment.
medicines: Antihistamines (e.g., Loratadine, Cetirizine, Diphenhydramine)
Decongestants (e.g., Pseudoephedrine for nasal congestion)
Corticosteroid nasal sprays (e.g., Fluticasone, Budesonide)
Leukotriene receptor antagonists (e.g., Montelukast for asthma-related allergies)
Epinephrine auto-injector (for severe allergic reactions like anaphylaxis)
Allergy shots (immunotherapy for long-term relief)

diseases.name: Bacterial Vaginosis
symptoms: Strong fishy odor, especially after intercourse
Itching or irritation in the vaginal area
precautions: Maintain good vaginal hygiene
Avoid douching, as it disrupts the natural vaginal flora
Use protection during sexual activity
Limit the number of sexual partners
Wear breathable cotton underwear
Avoid scented soaps and feminine hygiene sprays
Eat a balanced diet with probiotics (yogurt, fermented foods)
diseases.description: Bacterial Vaginosis (BV) is a common vaginal infection caused by an imbalance of bacteria in the vagina. It is not considered a sexually transmitted infection but is more common in sexually active women. While BV may resolve on its own, treatment is often recommended to prevent complications, especially during pregnancy.
medicines: Metronidazole (oral or vaginal gel)
Clindamycin (cream or oral antibiotics)
Tinidazole (oral antibiotic for resistant cases)
Probiotics (to restore healthy vaginal flora)

diseases.name: Bone Cancer
symptoms: Persistent bone pain that worsens over time
Swelling and tenderness near affected bones
Limited range of motion in affected limbs
Lump or mass in the affected bone
precautions: Maintain a healthy diet rich in calcium and vitamin D
Engage in regular physical activity to strengthen bones
Avoid exposure to radiation unless medically necessary
Seek medical attention for persistent bone pain
Undergo regular medical checkups if at high risk
Avoid smoking and excessive alcohol consumption
diseases.description: Bone cancer is a rare type of cancer that originates in the bone cells. It can develop in any bone but commonly affects the long bones in the arms and legs. There are different types, including osteosarcoma, chondrosarcoma, and Ewing sarcoma. Early detection and treatment, such as surgery, chemotherapy, or radiation therapy, improve survival rates.
medicines: Chemotherapy drugs (e.g., Methotrexate, Doxorubicin, Cisplatin)
Targeted therapy drugs (e.g., Denosumab for bone tumors)
Pain relievers (e.g., Morphine, Ibuprofen for symptom management)
Bisphosphonates (to strengthen bones and reduce fractures)
Radiation therapy (to shrink tumors before surgery)

diseases.name: Brain Tumors
symptoms: Persistent headaches that worsen over time
Nausea or vomiting, especially in the morning
precautions: Maintain a healthy diet rich in antioxidants
Avoid exposure to harmful radiation
Use protective headgear to prevent head injuries
Regular medical checkups for early detection
Avoid smoking and excessive alcohol consumption
Manage stress and maintain a balanced lifestyle
Stay physically active and maintain a healthy weight
diseases.description: Brain tumors are abnormal growths of cells in the brain, which can be benign (non-cancerous) or malignant (cancerous). Symptoms depend on the tumor's location, size, and growth rate. Treatment options include surgery, radiation therapy, chemotherapy, and targeted drug therapy.
medicines: Corticosteroids (e.g., Dexamethasone to reduce swelling)
Anticonvulsants (e.g., Levetiracetam for seizure control)
Chemotherapy drugs (e.g., Temozolomide for malignant tumors)
Targeted therapy drugs (e.g., Bevacizumab for glioblastoma)
Pain relievers (e.g., Morphine for severe pain management)
Radiation therapy (to shrink or destroy tumor cells)

diseases.name: Breast Cancer (Female)
symptoms: Lump or mass in the breast or underarm
Change in breast size or shape
Skin changes on the breast (dimpling, redness, or scaliness)
Swelling in part of the breast
Lymph node enlargement near the armpit or collarbone
precautions: Perform regular breast self-exams
Schedule routine mammograms for early detection
Maintain a healthy diet and exercise regularly
Limit alcohol consumption and avoid smoking
Maintain a healthy weight, especially after menopause
Be aware of family history and discuss risk factors with a doctor
Breastfeed if possible, as it may lower the risk
Avoid prolonged use of hormone replacement therapy (HRT) without medical guidance
diseases.description: Breast cancer is a type of cancer that forms in the breast tissue. It is the most common cancer among women worldwide. Early detection through screening and self-exams significantly improves treatment outcomes. Treatment may involve surgery, chemotherapy, radiation therapy, hormone therapy, or targeted therapy, depending on the stage and type of cancer.
medicines: Chemotherapy drugs (e.g., Doxorubicin, Paclitaxel, Cyclophosphamide)
Hormone therapy drugs (e.g., Tamoxifen, Letrozole for hormone-sensitive cancers)
Targeted therapy drugs (e.g., Trastuzumab for HER2-positive breast cancer)
Immunotherapy (e.g., Atezolizumab for triple-negative breast cancer)
Pain relievers (e.g., Ibuprofen, Morphine for symptom relief)
Radiation therapy (to destroy remaining cancer cells after surgery)

diseases.name: Breast Cancer (Male)
symptoms: Lump or swelling in the breast tissue
Redness or scaling of the nipple or breast skin
Swelling of lymph nodes near the armpit
precautions: Be aware of family history and genetic risks (BRCA1/BRCA2 mutations)
Perform regular self-exams to detect any lumps or changes
Limit alcohol consumption and avoid smoking
Maintain a healthy weight and exercise regularly
Consume a balanced diet rich in antioxidants
Avoid long-term hormone treatments unless medically necessary
Seek medical attention for any unusual breast changes
diseases.description: Breast cancer in men is rare but can occur due to abnormal cell growth in the breast tissue. Although men have less breast tissue than women, they can still develop breast cancer. Risk factors include age, genetic mutations, and hormonal imbalances. Early detection and treatment, including surgery, chemotherapy, and hormone therapy, can improve outcomes.
medicines: Chemotherapy drugs (e.g., Doxorubicin, Paclitaxel, Cyclophosphamide)
Hormone therapy drugs (e.g., Tamoxifen for hormone-sensitive breast cancer)
Targeted therapy drugs (e.g., Trastuzumab for HER2-positive breast cancer)
Pain relievers (e.g., Ibuprofen, Morphine for pain management)
Immunotherapy (e.g., Atezolizumab for advanced cases)
Radiation therapy (to destroy remaining cancer cells post-surgery)

diseases.name: Bronchitis
symptoms: Runny or stuffy nose (in viral bronchitis)
precautions: Avoid smoking and exposure to secondhand smoke
Wash hands regularly to prevent infections
Stay hydrated to thin mucus secretions
Use a humidifier to ease breathing
Get enough rest to support recovery
Avoid air pollutants and allergens
Wear a mask in polluted or dusty areas
Get vaccinated against flu and pneumonia (to reduce risk of bronchitis)
diseases.description: Bronchitis is an inflammation of the bronchial tubes, which carry air to and from the lungs. It can be acute (short-term, usually caused by viruses) or chronic (long-term, often due to smoking or environmental factors). Symptoms include persistent coughing, mucus production, and breathing difficulties.
medicines: Cough suppressants (e.g., Dextromethorphan for dry cough)
Expectorants (e.g., Guaifenesin to loosen mucus)
Bronchodilators (e.g., Albuterol for wheezing and shortness of breath)
Pain relievers (e.g., Ibuprofen, Acetaminophen for fever and body aches)
Antibiotics (only if bacterial infection is present)
Corticosteroids (for severe inflammation in chronic bronchitis)

diseases.name: Kidney Stones
symptoms: Severe pain in the lower back or side (renal colic)
Pain that radiates to the lower abdomen or groin
Fever and chills (if infection is present)
precautions: Drink plenty of water to stay hydrated
Reduce intake of salt and processed foods
Limit consumption of oxalate-rich foods (e.g., spinach, nuts, chocolate)
Avoid excessive intake of animal protein
Maintain a balanced diet with enough calcium
Exercise regularly to prevent obesity-related risks
Limit sugary beverages and sodas
Consult a doctor if you have a family history of kidney stones
diseases.description: Kidney stones are hard mineral and salt deposits that form in the kidneys. They can cause severe pain when they pass through the urinary tract. Factors like dehydration, diet, and genetics contribute to their formation. Small stones may pass on their own, while larger stones may require medical intervention such as lithotripsy or surgery.
medicines: Pain relievers (e.g., Ibuprofen, Acetaminophen for pain management)
Alpha-blockers (e.g., Tamsulosin to help pass stones more easily)
Diuretics (e.g., Thiazide diuretics to prevent stone formation)
Citrate supplements (e.g., Potassium citrate to prevent calcium stones)
Antibiotics (if infection is present)

diseases.name: Kidney Cancer
symptoms: Persistent lower back or side pain
Swelling in the abdomen or lower back
precautions: Avoid smoking, as it increases the risk of kidney cancer
Maintain a healthy weight through diet and exercise
Limit exposure to harmful chemicals (e.g., industrial toxins)
Control high blood pressure and diabetes
Stay well-hydrated by drinking enough water
Eat a diet rich in fruits, vegetables, and whole grains
Limit excessive protein and salt intake
Get regular medical checkups, especially if at high risk
diseases.description: Kidney cancer, also known as renal cancer, begins in the kidneys and can spread to other organs if left untreated. The most common type is renal cell carcinoma. Risk factors include smoking, obesity, high blood pressure, and family history. Treatment options depend on the stage and may include surgery, targeted therapy, immunotherapy, or radiation.
medicines: Targeted therapy drugs (e.g., Sunitinib, Pazopanib, Sorafenib)
Immunotherapy drugs (e.g., Nivolumab, Pembrolizumab, Interleukin-2)
Chemotherapy (less commonly used for kidney cancer)
Pain relievers (e.g., Acetaminophen, Morphine for symptom management)
Anti-hypertensive drugs (if kidney cancer causes high blood pressure)

diseases.name: Kidney Infection (Pyelonephritis)
symptoms: Pain in the lower back or side (flank pain)
Frequent urination with a strong urge
Painful or burning sensation during urination
precautions: Drink plenty of water to flush out bacteria
Practice good personal hygiene, especially after using the restroom
Urinate regularly and avoid holding urine for long periods
Wipe from front to back to prevent bacterial spread
Avoid excessive use of irritating feminine hygiene products
Take prescribed antibiotics as directed if prone to infections
Manage underlying conditions like diabetes that increase infection risk
Seek medical attention for recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs)
diseases.description: A kidney infection, also known as pyelonephritis, is a serious urinary tract infection (UTI) that affects one or both kidneys. It is usually caused by bacteria traveling from the bladder to the kidneys. If left untreated, it can lead to complications such as kidney damage or sepsis.
medicines: Antibiotics (e.g., Ciprofloxacin, Amoxicillin, Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole)
Pain relievers (e.g., Acetaminophen, Ibuprofen for fever and discomfort)
Anti-nausea medications (e.g., Ondansetron for nausea and vomiting)
Fluids and electrolytes (to maintain hydration and kidney function)

diseases.name: Womb (Uterus) Cancer
precautions: Maintain a healthy weight through diet and exercise
Manage diabetes and high blood pressure
Limit intake of processed and high-fat foods
Avoid smoking and excessive alcohol consumption
Use hormone therapy cautiously under medical supervision
Regular pelvic exams and screenings (especially for postmenopausal women)
Recognize family history and discuss genetic risks with a doctor
diseases.description: Womb (uterus) cancer, also known as endometrial cancer, is a type of cancer that begins in the lining of the uterus. It is the most common gynecological cancer and primarily affects postmenopausal women. Risk factors include obesity, hormone imbalances, and family history. Treatment options include surgery, radiation, chemotherapy, and hormone therapy.
medicines: Chemotherapy drugs (e.g., Paclitaxel, Carboplatin, Doxorubicin)
Hormone therapy (e.g., Medroxyprogesterone, Tamoxifen for hormone-sensitive cancer)
Targeted therapy drugs (e.g., Lenvatinib, Pembrolizumab for advanced cases)
Pain relievers (e.g., Acetaminophen, Ibuprofen for symptom relief)
Radiation therapy (for localized tumor control)

diseases.name: Vertigo
precautions: Avoid sudden head movements or position changes
Stay hydrated and maintain a balanced diet
Limit caffeine, alcohol, and salt intake
Manage stress and anxiety through relaxation techniques
Avoid bright lights or screens during episodes
Use handrails or support when moving to prevent falls
Perform vestibular rehabilitation exercises if recommended by a doctor
Get regular checkups for underlying ear or neurological conditions
diseases.description: Vertigo is a sensation of dizziness or spinning, often caused by inner ear problems, vestibular disorders, or neurological conditions. Common causes include benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV), Meniere’s disease, and vestibular neuritis. Treatment depends on the underlying cause and may include medications, exercises, or lifestyle adjustments.
medicines: Antihistamines (e.g., Meclizine, Dimenhydrinate for motion sickness)
Benzodiazepines (e.g., Diazepam, Lorazepam for severe vertigo)
Antiemetics (e.g., Promethazine, Metoclopramide for nausea and vomiting)
Vestibular suppressants (e.g., Betahistine for inner ear disorders)
Corticosteroids (e.g., Prednisone for inflammation-related vertigo)
Diuretics (e.g., Hydrochlorothiazide for Meniere’s disease)

diseases.name: Vomiting in Children and Babies
symptoms: Dehydration (dry mouth, no tears, less urination)
precautions: Ensure the child stays hydrated with small sips of water or oral rehydration solutions
Avoid giving solid foods until vomiting stops
Feed small, frequent meals instead of large portions
Keep the child in an upright position after feeding
Avoid dairy or sugary drinks if they worsen symptoms
Ensure proper hygiene to prevent infections
Consult a doctor if vomiting is persistent, has blood, or is accompanied by high fever
diseases.description: Vomiting in children and babies can be caused by infections, food intolerance, motion sickness, or gastrointestinal issues. It is essential to monitor for dehydration and provide proper care. In most cases, vomiting resolves on its own, but medical attention is needed for severe or prolonged symptoms.
medicines: Oral rehydration solutions (e.g., Pedialyte for dehydration)
Anti-nausea medication (e.g., Ondansetron for severe vomiting, only if prescribed)
Probiotics (e.g., Lactobacillus for digestive balance)
Fever reducers (e.g., Acetaminophen if fever is present)
Electrolyte drinks (for mild cases to prevent dehydration)

diseases.name: Vomiting in Adults
symptoms: Nausea followed by forceful expulsion of stomach contents
precautions: Drink small sips of water or oral rehydration solutions to stay hydrated
Avoid solid foods until vomiting stops
Stick to a bland diet (e.g., bananas, rice, applesauce, toast)
Rest and avoid physical exertion
Avoid alcohol, caffeine, and dairy products until recovery
Identify and avoid food triggers (e.g., spicy, fatty, or contaminated foods)
Take medications only as prescribed for nausea and vomiting
Seek medical attention if vomiting is persistent, contains blood, or is accompanied by severe pain
diseases.description: Vomiting in adults can be caused by food poisoning, infections, motion sickness, pregnancy, gastrointestinal disorders, or underlying medical conditions. While most cases resolve with home care, prolonged vomiting may lead to dehydration and require medical attention.
medicines: Oral rehydration solutions (e.g., ORS packets for dehydration prevention)
Antiemetics (e.g., Ondansetron, Promethazine for nausea and vomiting)
Proton pump inhibitors (e.g., Omeprazole for acid-related vomiting)
Antacids (e.g., Ranitidine, Calcium carbonate for indigestion-related vomiting)
Pain relievers (e.g., Acetaminophen for fever or headache if needed)

diseases.name: Urinary Tract Infection (UTI)
precautions: Drink plenty of water to flush out bacteria
Urinate regularly and do not hold urine for long periods
Wipe from front to back to prevent bacteria from spreading
Avoid using irritating feminine hygiene products
Wear breathable cotton underwear and avoid tight clothing
Take showers instead of baths
Urinate after sexual activity to reduce infection risk
Avoid excessive caffeine and alcohol, which can irritate the bladder
diseases.description: A urinary tract infection (UTI) is a bacterial infection affecting any part of the urinary system, including the bladder, kidneys, ureters, and urethra. It is more common in women but can affect men as well. UTIs can cause discomfort and, if left untreated, may lead to serious kidney infections.
medicines: Antibiotics (e.g., Nitrofurantoin, Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, Ciprofloxacin)
Pain relievers (e.g., Phenazopyridine for urinary discomfort, Acetaminophen for fever)
Probiotics (e.g., Lactobacillus for gut and urinary health)
Cranberry supplements (may help prevent recurring UTIs)
Increased water intake and electrolyte balance solutions

diseases.name: Thyroid Disorders
symptoms: Unexplained weight gain or weight loss
Changes in heart rate (slow in hypothyroidism, fast in hyperthyroidism)
precautions: Maintain a balanced diet rich in iodine, selenium, and zinc
Regularly check thyroid hormone levels if at risk
Manage stress through yoga, meditation, and relaxation techniques
Avoid excessive consumption of goitrogenic foods (e.g., cabbage, soy, broccoli) if advised
Ensure adequate vitamin D and B12 levels
Stay physically active to maintain metabolism
Take prescribed medications consistently
Avoid self-medicating with herbal or iodine supplements without medical advice
diseases.description: Thyroid disorders include hypothyroidism (underactive thyroid) and hyperthyroidism (overactive thyroid). The thyroid gland regulates metabolism, energy, and hormone balance. Disorders may result from autoimmune conditions like Hashimoto’s thyroiditis or Graves’ disease, iodine deficiency, or genetic factors.
medicines: Levothyroxine (for hypothyroidism to replace thyroid hormones)
Methimazole, Propylthiouracil (for hyperthyroidism to reduce hormone production)
Beta-blockers (e.g., Propranolol to manage hyperthyroidism symptoms)
Radioactive iodine therapy (for severe hyperthyroidism or thyroid cancer)
Surgical removal of the thyroid (for severe cases or cancer)
Vitamin D and selenium supplements (if deficiency-related)

diseases.name: Testicular Cancer
symptoms: A lump or swelling in one testicle
A feeling of heaviness in the scrotum
Dull ache or pain in the lower abdomen or groin
Enlargement or tenderness of the breasts (gynecomastia)
Sudden collection of fluid in the scrotum
Pain or discomfort in the testicle or scrotum
Unexplained fatigue or general feeling of unwellness
precautions: Perform regular testicular self-examinations to detect lumps early
Maintain a healthy lifestyle with a balanced diet and regular exercise
Avoid exposure to harmful chemicals and radiation
Wear protective gear during sports to prevent testicular injury
Limit excessive alcohol consumption and avoid smoking
Seek medical advice if you notice any testicular changes
Discuss family history with a doctor if testicular cancer runs in the family
diseases.description: Testicular cancer is a rare but highly treatable cancer that develops in the testicles, typically affecting younger men between the ages of 15 and 40. It may present as a painless lump or swelling and can spread if not detected early. Risk factors include undescended testicles, family history, and genetic conditions.
medicines: Chemotherapy drugs (e.g., Bleomycin, Etoposide, Cisplatin for advanced stages)
Radiation therapy (used for seminoma-type testicular cancer)
Pain relievers (e.g., Ibuprofen, Acetaminophen for pain management)
Hormone therapy (if needed after treatment)
Surgical removal of the affected testicle (orchiectomy, the primary treatment)

diseases.name: Threadworms (Pinworms)
symptoms: Itching around the anus, especially at night
Disturbed sleep due to itching and discomfort
Visible white, thread-like worms in stool or around the anus
precautions: Wash hands thoroughly with soap and water, especially before eating and after using the toilet
Keep fingernails short and discourage nail-biting
Wash bed linens, clothes, and towels in hot water regularly
Clean toilet seats, bathroom surfaces, and household items frequently
Avoid scratching the anal area to prevent reinfection
Ensure all family members are treated if one person is infected
Wear tight-fitting underwear to prevent eggs from spreading
Take a morning shower to remove eggs from the skin
diseases.description: Threadworms (pinworms) are tiny parasitic worms that infect the intestines, commonly affecting children. They cause intense itching around the anus, especially at night. The infection spreads through contact with contaminated surfaces, hands, or food. Proper hygiene and medication help eliminate the worms.
medicines: Mebendazole (common treatment for threadworms)
Albendazole (alternative treatment for pinworms)
Pyrantel pamoate (available over-the-counter for worm infections)
Antihistamines (e.g., Loratadine for itching relief if severe)
Zinc oxide ointment (to soothe irritated skin around the anus)

diseases.name: Thyroid Cancer
symptoms: A lump or swelling in the neck
Pain in the throat or neck
Swollen lymph nodes in the neck
Persistent cough not caused by a cold
precautions: Regular neck self-examinations to detect lumps early
Maintain a healthy diet rich in iodine and antioxidants
Avoid excessive radiation exposure to the neck
Undergo routine thyroid function tests if at risk
Seek medical advice if experiencing persistent throat discomfort or swelling
Limit exposure to environmental toxins and chemicals
Follow doctor’s recommendations for managing thyroid nodules
diseases.description: Thyroid cancer is a type of cancer that develops in the thyroid gland, located at the base of the neck. It is more common in women and may be associated with genetic factors, radiation exposure, or existing thyroid conditions. Most thyroid cancers are treatable with early detection and proper medical intervention.
medicines: Levothyroxine (to replace thyroid hormones after treatment)
Radioactive iodine therapy (used to destroy remaining cancer cells after surgery)
Chemotherapy drugs (e.g., Doxorubicin for advanced cases)
Targeted therapy drugs (e.g., Sorafenib, Lenvatinib for aggressive thyroid cancer)
Pain relievers (e.g., Acetaminophen for post-surgical discomfort)

diseases.name: Tooth Decay (Cavities)
symptoms: Visible holes or pits in teeth
Sensitivity to hot, cold, or sweet foods and drinks
Brown, black, or white staining on teeth
Swelling or pus around the affected tooth (in severe cases)
Bad breath or an unpleasant taste in the mouth
precautions: Brush teeth twice daily with fluoride toothpaste
Floss daily to remove plaque between teeth
Reduce consumption of sugary and acidic foods and drinks
Drink plenty of water, especially fluoridated water
Visit the dentist regularly for check-ups and cleanings
Use antibacterial mouthwash to reduce plaque buildup
Avoid smoking and excessive alcohol consumption
Chew sugar-free gum to stimulate saliva production
diseases.description: Tooth decay, also known as dental caries or cavities, occurs when bacteria in the mouth produce acids that damage the tooth enamel. It is a common oral health problem that can lead to pain, infections, and tooth loss if untreated. Proper oral hygiene and regular dental care help prevent cavities.
medicines: Fluoride toothpaste or mouthwash (to strengthen enamel)
Antibacterial mouth rinse (e.g., Chlorhexidine for plaque control)
Pain relievers (e.g., Ibuprofen, Acetaminophen for toothache relief)
Calcium and phosphate-based remineralizing agents (e.g., CPP-ACP creams)
Dental fillings, crowns, or root canal treatment (for advanced decay)

diseases.name: Stomach Cancer (Gastric Cancer)
symptoms: Feeling full after eating small amounts
precautions: Eat a healthy diet rich in fruits, vegetables, and whole grains
Avoid processed and smoked foods high in salt and nitrates
Limit alcohol consumption and avoid smoking
Maintain a healthy weight and exercise regularly
Seek medical attention for persistent digestive issues
Manage Helicobacter pylori (H. pylori) infection with proper treatment
Undergo regular screenings if at high risk due to family history
diseases.description: Stomach cancer, also known as gastric cancer, develops in the lining of the stomach. It often progresses silently in the early stages, making early detection difficult. Risk factors include Helicobacter pylori infection, smoking, poor diet, and a family history of gastric cancer. Treatment options depend on the stage and may include surgery, chemotherapy, or radiation therapy.
medicines: Chemotherapy drugs (e.g., Cisplatin, 5-Fluorouracil, Paclitaxel)
Targeted therapy drugs (e.g., Trastuzumab for HER2-positive gastric cancer)
Immunotherapy (e.g., Nivolumab for advanced stages)
Pain relievers (e.g., Acetaminophen, Ibuprofen for symptom relief)
Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) (e.g., Omeprazole for acid control)
Antiemetic drugs (e.g., Ondansetron to reduce nausea)

diseases.name: Skin Cancer
symptoms: New or changing mole or skin growth
A sore that does not heal
Itching, tenderness, or pain in a mole or skin lesion
Redness or swelling beyond the border of a mole
Scaly or rough patches on the skin
Bleeding or oozing from a skin lesion
Dark streaks under nails (in some cases)
precautions: Avoid excessive sun exposure, especially during peak hours (10 AM - 4 PM)
Use broad-spectrum sunscreen (SPF 30 or higher) daily
Wear protective clothing, hats, and sunglasses outdoors
Avoid tanning beds and artificial UV exposure
Regularly check your skin for any new or changing moles or spots
Visit a dermatologist for routine skin screenings
Maintain a healthy diet rich in antioxidants to support skin health
diseases.description: Skin cancer is the abnormal growth of skin cells, often caused by excessive UV exposure. The most common types include basal cell carcinoma, squamous cell carcinoma, and melanoma, the most aggressive form. Early detection and prevention are key to reducing the risk and severity of skin cancer.
medicines: Topical chemotherapy (e.g., 5-Fluorouracil for early-stage cancers)
Immunotherapy (e.g., Pembrolizumab for advanced melanoma)
Targeted therapy (e.g., Vemurafenib for specific genetic mutations in melanoma)
Pain relievers (e.g., Acetaminophen, Ibuprofen for symptom management)
Surgical excision or Mohs surgery (for localized skin cancer)
Radiation therapy (used for advanced or inoperable cases)

diseases.name: Ringworm and Other Fungal Infections
symptoms: Red, scaly, or itchy patches on the skin
Circular rash with a raised border (common in ringworm)
Blisters or cracking of the skin
White patches on the tongue or inside the mouth (oral thrush)
Brittle, discolored, or thickened nails (nail fungus)
Burning or itching between the toes (athlete's foot)
precautions: Keep skin clean and dry, especially in moist areas like the feet and groin
Avoid sharing personal items such as towels, socks, and shoes
Wear breathable, moisture-wicking clothing
Change socks and underwear daily
Use antifungal powders or sprays in shoes and socks
Disinfect floors and shared surfaces to prevent spreading
Avoid walking barefoot in public places like locker rooms and pools
diseases.description: Ringworm and other fungal infections are caused by dermatophytes, yeast, or mold. These infections affect the skin, scalp, nails, and mucous membranes. Common fungal infections include athlete's foot, jock itch, nail fungus, and oral thrush. Proper hygiene, antifungal treatments, and preventive measures can help manage and prevent recurrence.
medicines: Topical antifungals (e.g., Clotrimazole, Miconazole, Terbinafine for mild infections)
Oral antifungals (e.g., Fluconazole, Itraconazole for severe cases)
Antifungal shampoos (e.g., Ketoconazole for scalp infections)
Antifungal nail treatments (e.g., Ciclopirox, Efinaconazole for nail fungus)
Antiseptic creams (e.g., Tolnaftate to prevent secondary infections)
Hydrocortisone (to reduce itching and inflammation)

diseases.name: Pulmonary Hypertension
symptoms: Shortness of breath, especially during activity
Swelling in the ankles, legs, or abdomen
precautions: Maintain a heart-healthy diet low in salt and processed foods
Engage in light, regular physical activity as recommended by a doctor
Avoid smoking and limit alcohol consumption
Monitor oxygen levels and seek supplemental oxygen therapy if necessary
Take prescribed medications regularly and follow up with a cardiologist
Manage underlying conditions such as lung disease or heart failure
Avoid high altitudes, as low oxygen levels can worsen symptoms
Reduce stress and practice relaxation techniques
diseases.description: Pulmonary hypertension is a condition in which high blood pressure occurs in the arteries of the lungs, leading to increased strain on the heart. It can be caused by heart or lung diseases, genetic factors, or unknown reasons (idiopathic pulmonary hypertension). Without treatment, it can progress to heart failure.
medicines: Endothelin receptor antagonists (e.g., Bosentan, Ambrisentan to relax blood vessels)
Phosphodiesterase inhibitors (e.g., Sildenafil, Tadalafil to improve blood flow)
Prostacyclin analogs (e.g., Epoprostenol, Treprostinil to dilate blood vessels)
Diuretics (e.g., Furosemide to reduce fluid buildup)
Blood thinners (e.g., Warfarin to prevent clot formation)
Oxygen therapy (to improve oxygen levels in the blood)

diseases.name: Obesity
symptoms: Shortness of breath with mild activity
Increased risk of heart disease, diabetes, and high blood pressure
precautions: Maintain a balanced diet rich in fruits, vegetables, and whole grains
Avoid sugary drinks, processed foods, and excessive calorie intake
Engage in regular physical activity (at least 150 minutes per week)
Monitor portion sizes and practice mindful eating
Stay hydrated by drinking plenty of water
Get enough sleep to regulate metabolism and hormones
Manage stress through meditation, yoga, or counseling
Seek medical advice for weight management plans
diseases.description: Obesity is a chronic condition characterized by excessive body fat that increases the risk of various health issues, including heart disease, diabetes, hypertension, and joint problems. It is primarily caused by an imbalance between calorie intake and energy expenditure, often influenced by genetic, behavioral, and environmental factors.
medicines: Orlistat (reduces fat absorption)
Liraglutide (appetite suppressant and weight loss aid)
Phentermine-Topiramate (appetite suppressant)
Metformin (for weight management in diabetics)
Bariatric surgery (for severe obesity cases)
Lifestyle changes (diet and exercise as primary treatment)

diseases.name: Mouth Cancer
symptoms: Persistent sores or ulcers in the mouth that do not heal
Red or white patches inside the mouth
Lumps or thickened areas in the cheek or tongue
Numbness or pain in the mouth or lips
precautions: Avoid tobacco products, including cigarettes and chewing tobacco
Limit alcohol consumption
Maintain good oral hygiene and visit a dentist regularly
Eat a healthy diet rich in fruits and vegetables
Avoid excessive sun exposure on the lips and use lip balm with SPF
Get vaccinated against HPV (Human Papillomavirus), a risk factor for oral cancer
Seek medical attention for persistent mouth sores or changes
diseases.description: Mouth cancer, or oral cancer, refers to the abnormal growth of cells in the mouth, including the lips, tongue, gums, and inner cheeks. It is often linked to tobacco use, heavy alcohol consumption, and HPV infection. Early detection improves treatment outcomes, and prevention includes lifestyle changes and regular dental checkups.
medicines: Chemotherapy drugs (e.g., Cisplatin, Fluorouracil)
Targeted therapy (e.g., Cetuximab for advanced cases)
Pain management (e.g., Acetaminophen, Ibuprofen, Morphine for severe pain)
Nutritional support (e.g., high-calorie supplements for difficulty eating)
Surgical removal of tumors (for localized cases)
Radiation therapy (to destroy cancer cells and shrink tumors)

diseases.name: Mouth Ulcer
symptoms: Painful sores inside the mouth (cheeks, tongue, gums, or lips)
Round or oval-shaped ulcers with a white, yellow, or red border
Burning or tingling sensation before ulcers appear
precautions: Avoid spicy, acidic, or rough-textured foods that can irritate ulcers
Maintain good oral hygiene by brushing and flossing regularly
Use a soft-bristled toothbrush to prevent irritation
Stay hydrated and consume a balanced diet rich in vitamins B12, iron, and folate
Avoid chewing tobacco and smoking
Reduce stress through relaxation techniques like meditation or yoga
Use an antiseptic mouthwash or salt water rinse to prevent infection
diseases.description: Mouth ulcers, also known as canker sores, are painful sores that develop inside the mouth. They can be caused by stress, vitamin deficiencies, injury, hormonal changes, or certain medical conditions. While most mouth ulcers heal on their own within 1-2 weeks, severe or persistent cases may require medical treatment.
medicines: Topical anesthetics (e.g., Benzocaine gel, Lidocaine for pain relief)
Antiseptic mouthwashes (e.g., Chlorhexidine to prevent infection)
Anti-inflammatory gels (e.g., Triamcinolone for severe cases)
Vitamin supplements (e.g., Vitamin B12, Iron, Folate for deficiency-related ulcers)
Pain relievers (e.g., Paracetamol, Ibuprofen for discomfort)
Oral steroids (for severe or recurrent ulcers under medical supervision)

diseases.name: Migraine
symptoms: Severe, throbbing headache, usually on one side of the head
Sensitivity to light, sound, or smells
Tingling or numbness in the face or extremities
precautions: Maintain a regular sleep schedule and get enough rest
Avoid known migraine triggers such as caffeine, alcohol, and processed foods
Stay hydrated and eat regular, balanced meals
Manage stress through relaxation techniques like meditation and yoga
Limit exposure to bright lights and loud noises
Engage in regular physical activity, but avoid overexertion
Keep a migraine diary to track triggers and symptoms
Consult a doctor for appropriate treatment if migraines are frequent or severe
diseases.description: Migraine is a neurological condition characterized by intense, recurrent headaches that can be accompanied by nausea, sensitivity to light and sound, and visual disturbances. It can be triggered by stress, certain foods, hormonal changes, or environmental factors. Treatment focuses on symptom relief and prevention.
medicines: Pain relievers (e.g., Ibuprofen, Acetaminophen for mild migraines)
Triptans (e.g., Sumatriptan, Rizatriptan to reduce inflammation and relieve pain)
Ergotamine (for migraines that last more than 48 hours)
Anti-nausea medications (e.g., Metoclopramide, Domperidone)
Beta-blockers (e.g., Propranolol for migraine prevention)
Antidepressants (e.g., Amitriptyline for chronic migraines)
CGRP inhibitors (e.g., Erenumab, Fremanezumab for severe cases)

diseases.name: Miscarriage
symptoms: Passing tissue or clots from the vagina
Loss of pregnancy symptoms (e.g., nausea, breast tenderness)
Fever or chills (in cases of infection)
precautions: Avoid smoking, alcohol, and illicit drugs
Maintain a healthy diet rich in essential vitamins and minerals
Stay hydrated and get adequate rest
Manage stress through relaxation techniques like yoga and meditation
Avoid heavy lifting and strenuous physical activity
Regular prenatal checkups to monitor pregnancy health
Address underlying medical conditions (e.g., diabetes, thyroid disorders)
Seek medical advice if experiencing unusual symptoms during pregnancy
diseases.description: A miscarriage is the loss of a pregnancy before the 20th week. It can be caused by genetic abnormalities, infections, hormonal imbalances, or maternal health conditions. Symptoms often include vaginal bleeding, cramping, and passing of tissue. While many miscarriages occur due to uncontrollable factors, proper prenatal care can help reduce risks.
medicines: Misoprostol (to help pass remaining pregnancy tissue in early miscarriage)
Pain relievers (e.g., Ibuprofen, Acetaminophen for pain management)
Antibiotics (if an infection is present)
Hormonal therapy (e.g., Progesterone in cases of hormone-related pregnancy loss)
Blood thinners (e.g., Heparin, Aspirin for clotting disorders affecting pregnancy)
Emotional support and counseling for mental well-being

diseases.name: Malnutrition
symptoms: Swelling in the legs, feet, or abdomen (in severe cases)
Frequent infections due to a weakened immune system
Irritability, mood changes, or difficulty concentrating
precautions: Consume a balanced diet rich in proteins, vitamins, and minerals
Increase intake of nutrient-dense foods such as fruits, vegetables, whole grains, and lean proteins
Ensure adequate hydration by drinking enough water
Avoid excessive consumption of processed foods and sugary drinks
Provide nutritional supplements if recommended by a doctor
Regular health checkups to monitor nutritional status
Address underlying medical conditions affecting nutrient absorption
Encourage proper infant and child nutrition, including breastfeeding when possible
diseases.description: Malnutrition is a condition that occurs when the body does not get enough essential nutrients due to an imbalanced diet, poor absorption, or medical conditions. It can lead to weakness, poor immunity, and severe health complications if not treated. Malnutrition affects people of all ages, but it is particularly dangerous in children, the elderly, and those with chronic illnesses.
medicines: Multivitamins and mineral supplements (e.g., Vitamin A, Iron, Zinc, B-complex)
Nutritional supplements (e.g., high-calorie and high-protein drinks)
Oral rehydration solutions (for cases involving dehydration)
Parenteral nutrition (IV nutrition for severe malnutrition)
Specialized dietary plans (under medical supervision)
Treatment of underlying conditions affecting nutrient absorption (e.g., deworming medications for parasitic infections)

diseases.name: Lymphoedema
symptoms: Swelling in the arms, legs, or other parts of the body
Heaviness or tightness in the affected limb
Recurring infections in the affected area
Hardening or thickening of the skin (fibrosis)
Aching or discomfort in the swollen area
Skin discoloration or changes in texture
Fluid leakage from the skin in severe cases
precautions: Avoid injuries, cuts, or burns on the affected area to prevent infections
Maintain proper hygiene and moisturize the skin to prevent dryness
Wear compression garments to reduce swelling and improve circulation
Elevate the affected limb when resting
Engage in gentle exercises to promote lymphatic drainage
Avoid tight clothing or accessories that restrict lymph flow
Maintain a healthy weight and balanced diet
Seek medical advice if swelling worsens or infections occur
diseases.description: Lymphoedema is a long-term condition caused by a buildup of lymphatic fluid in tissues, leading to swelling, discomfort, and an increased risk of infections. It can be congenital (primary) or result from damage to the lymphatic system due to surgery, cancer treatment, infections, or other health conditions.
medicines: Antibiotics (e.g., Amoxicillin, Flucloxacillin for infections)
Pain relievers (e.g., Paracetamol, Ibuprofen for discomfort)
Diuretics (in some cases, to reduce fluid retention)
Lymphatic drainage therapy (manual lymphatic drainage by a therapist)
Compression therapy (specialized bandages or garments to control swelling)
Skin care treatments (to prevent infections and complications)

diseases.name: Liver Cancer
symptoms: Swelling or bloating in the abdomen
Jaundice (yellowing of the skin and eyes)
precautions: Avoid excessive alcohol consumption
Maintain a healthy weight and balanced diet
Get vaccinated against hepatitis B
Manage chronic liver diseases (e.g., hepatitis C, cirrhosis)
Limit exposure to toxins and chemicals harmful to the liver
Exercise regularly to maintain overall health
Avoid smoking and tobacco use
Undergo regular liver screenings if at high risk
diseases.description: Liver cancer is a malignant tumor that originates in the liver cells. It is commonly linked to chronic liver disease, hepatitis infections, and cirrhosis. Symptoms may not appear in the early stages, making early diagnosis crucial. Treatment options depend on the stage and severity of the cancer.
medicines: Targeted therapy drugs (e.g., Sorafenib, Lenvatinib for advanced liver cancer)
Immunotherapy (e.g., Atezolizumab, Nivolumab to boost immune response)
Chemotherapy (e.g., Doxorubicin, Cisplatin in advanced cases)
Pain relievers (e.g., Paracetamol, Ibuprofen for symptom management)
Antiviral medications (for hepatitis-related liver cancer)
Liver transplant or surgery (for eligible patients)

diseases.name: Liver Tumors
symptoms: Abdominal pain or discomfort, especially in the upper right side
Swelling or bloating in the abdomen
Jaundice (yellowing of the skin and eyes)
precautions: Limit alcohol consumption to reduce liver damage
Maintain a healthy weight and balanced diet
Avoid exposure to hepatitis B and C by practicing safe hygiene and getting vaccinated
Monitor liver health if diagnosed with cirrhosis or chronic liver disease
Undergo regular medical screenings if at high risk
Avoid unnecessary exposure to environmental toxins and harmful chemicals
Exercise regularly to support liver function
Consult a doctor for early detection and treatment
diseases.description: Liver tumors are abnormal growths that develop in the liver. They can be benign (non-cancerous) or malignant (cancerous). While benign tumors usually do not cause severe symptoms, malignant tumors, such as hepatocellular carcinoma, can be life-threatening if not treated early. Risk factors include chronic liver diseases, hepatitis infections, and cirrhosis.
medicines: Targeted therapy drugs (e.g., Sorafenib, Lenvatinib for cancerous liver tumors)
Immunotherapy (e.g., Atezolizumab, Nivolumab for malignant tumors)
Pain relievers (e.g., Acetaminophen, Ibuprofen for symptom relief)
Antiviral medications (e.g., Tenofovir, Entecavir for hepatitis-related tumors)
Chemotherapy (e.g., Doxorubicin, Cisplatin in cases of malignant tumors)
Surgical removal or liver transplant (for eligible patients with large or malignant tumors)

diseases.name: Infertility
symptoms: Inability to conceive after one year of regular, unprotected intercourse
Irregular or absent menstrual cycles (in women)
Hormonal imbalances (e.g., acne, excessive hair growth, weight gain)
Erectile dysfunction or low sperm count (in men)
Pelvic pain or underlying reproductive disorders (e.g., PCOS, endometriosis)
precautions: Maintain a healthy weight through a balanced diet and regular exercise
Avoid smoking, excessive alcohol consumption, and recreational drugs
Manage stress through relaxation techniques like meditation or yoga
Monitor ovulation cycles for better timing of conception
Avoid exposure to environmental toxins and radiation
Treat underlying medical conditions affecting fertility (e.g., thyroid disorders, diabetes)
Ensure adequate intake of essential vitamins and minerals (e.g., folic acid, zinc)
Consult a fertility specialist if struggling to conceive after a year
diseases.description: Infertility is the inability to conceive despite regular, unprotected sexual intercourse for at least one year. It can affect both men and women due to hormonal imbalances, reproductive disorders, lifestyle factors, or underlying medical conditions. Various treatments, including medications, assisted reproductive technologies, and lifestyle changes, can improve fertility outcomes.
medicines: Clomiphene citrate (to stimulate ovulation in women)
Letrozole (for ovulation induction, especially in PCOS patients)
Gonadotropins (e.g., FSH, hCG injections for egg or sperm production)
Metformin (for insulin resistance-related infertility, such as PCOS)
Bromocriptine (for treating high prolactin levels affecting ovulation)
Antioxidant supplements (e.g., Coenzyme Q10, vitamin C, zinc for sperm health)
Hormonal therapy (e.g., testosterone replacement for male infertility)
Assisted reproductive techniques (e.g., IVF, IUI for severe cases)

diseases.name: Eye Cancer
symptoms: Partial or complete loss of vision
A dark spot or growth on the iris or inside the eye
Flashing lights or floaters in vision
Pain in or around the eye (in advanced stages)
Change in the size or shape of the pupil
Redness or swelling in the eye
precautions: Regular eye checkups for early detection
Wear UV-protective sunglasses to protect from harmful radiation
Avoid prolonged exposure to bright lights and harmful chemicals
Maintain a healthy lifestyle with a balanced diet rich in antioxidants
Quit smoking and limit alcohol intake
Monitor any unusual changes in vision and consult an ophthalmologist
Manage underlying conditions like diabetes that can affect eye health
Genetic counseling if there is a family history of eye cancer
diseases.description: Eye cancer is a rare type of cancer that affects the eye tissues, including the retina, iris, or optic nerve. It can be primary (originating in the eye) or secondary (spreading from other body parts). The most common type is ocular melanoma. Early detection is crucial to prevent vision loss and spread to other organs.
medicines: Chemotherapy drugs (e.g., Carboplatin, Vincristine for advanced eye cancer)
Targeted therapy (e.g., MEK inhibitors for ocular melanoma)
Immunotherapy (e.g., Checkpoint inhibitors for metastatic cases)
Pain relievers (e.g., Acetaminophen, Ibuprofen for symptom management)
Radiation therapy (e.g., Brachytherapy for localized tumors)
Surgical intervention (e.g., enucleation in severe cases)

diseases.name: Endometriosis
symptoms: Pain during or after sexual intercourse
Painful bowel movements or urination, especially during periods
Bloating, nausea, and digestive issues (e.g., diarrhea or constipation)
precautions: Maintain a healthy diet rich in anti-inflammatory foods (e.g., leafy greens, omega-3 fatty acids)
Exercise regularly to improve circulation and reduce pain
Manage stress with relaxation techniques like yoga and meditation
Avoid excessive caffeine and alcohol intake
Monitor menstrual cycles and track symptoms
Use heat therapy (e.g., heating pads) to relieve pelvic pain
Consult a gynecologist for early diagnosis and treatment
Consider hormonal therapy if prescribed by a doctor
diseases.description: Endometriosis is a painful condition where tissue similar to the lining of the uterus grows outside the uterus. This tissue can cause inflammation, scarring, and pain, often worsening during menstruation. It is a leading cause of infertility in women and requires medical intervention for effective management.
medicines: Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) (e.g., Ibuprofen, Naproxen for pain relief)
Hormonal contraceptives (e.g., birth control pills, patches, or vaginal rings to regulate menstruation)
Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonists (e.g., Leuprolide to reduce estrogen levels)
Progestin therapy (e.g., Norethindrone, Medroxyprogesterone to suppress endometrial growth)
Aromatase inhibitors (e.g., Letrozole, Anastrozole to lower estrogen production)
Surgical treatments (e.g., laparoscopic surgery to remove endometrial tissue)

diseases.name: Epilepsy
symptoms: Seizures (uncontrolled shaking, muscle stiffness, or loss of awareness)
Uncontrollable jerking movements of the arms and legs
Psychological symptoms such as fear, anxiety, or déjà vu
Unusual sensations (e.g., tingling, flashing lights, or strange smells)
precautions: Take prescribed medications regularly to control seizures
Avoid sleep deprivation, as lack of sleep can trigger seizures
Manage stress through relaxation techniques like yoga or meditation
Avoid alcohol and recreational drugs
Wear protective gear (e.g., helmets) if at risk of falls due to seizures
Monitor for seizure triggers (e.g., flashing lights, dehydration, or stress)
Maintain a balanced diet and stay hydrated
Inform family and friends about first aid for seizures
diseases.description: Epilepsy is a neurological disorder characterized by recurrent seizures caused by abnormal brain activity. It can develop due to genetic factors, brain injuries, infections, or unknown causes. While epilepsy cannot always be cured, medications and lifestyle adjustments help manage the condition effectively.
medicines: Anti-epileptic drugs (AEDs) (e.g., Levetiracetam, Valproate, Carbamazepine, Phenytoin)
Benzodiazepines (e.g., Clonazepam, Diazepam for emergency seizure control)
Ketogenic diet (high-fat, low-carb diet for seizure management in drug-resistant epilepsy)
Vagus nerve stimulation (VNS) therapy for drug-resistant epilepsy
Surgical interventions (e.g., lobectomy, corpus callosotomy for severe cases)

diseases.name: Depression
symptoms: Loss of interest or pleasure in activities once enjoyed
Changes in appetite (weight loss or gain)
Feelings of worthlessness, guilt, or hopelessness
Physical symptoms such as headaches, digestive problems, or body pain
precautions: Engage in regular physical activity and exercise
Maintain a healthy, balanced diet
Practice relaxation techniques such as meditation and deep breathing
Ensure a consistent sleep schedule
Stay socially connected with family and friends
Avoid alcohol and recreational drugs
Seek professional counseling or therapy if symptoms persist
Follow prescribed medication regimen if applicable
diseases.description: Depression is a mental health disorder characterized by persistent feelings of sadness, hopelessness, and a lack of interest in daily activities. It can affect a person’s emotional and physical well-being, leading to difficulties in daily life. Treatment options include therapy, medication, and lifestyle changes.
medicines: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) (e.g., Fluoxetine, Sertraline, Escitalopram)
Serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs) (e.g., Venlafaxine, Duloxetine)
Tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) (e.g., Amitriptyline, Nortriptyline)
Monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs) (e.g., Phenelzine, Tranylcypromine for severe cases)
Atypical antidepressants (e.g., Bupropion, Mirtazapine)
Psychotherapy (e.g., Cognitive Behavioral Therapy, Dialectical Behavior Therapy)
Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) for treatment-resistant cases

diseases.name: Dental Abscess
symptoms: Swelling in the face or cheek
Sensitivity to hot and cold foods or drinks
Bad breath or a foul taste in the mouth
Pus drainage from the affected area
precautions: Maintain good oral hygiene by brushing twice a day and flossing daily
Visit the dentist regularly for checkups and cleanings
Avoid consuming excessive sugary foods and drinks
Rinse your mouth with warm salt water to reduce infection risk
Use a soft-bristled toothbrush to prevent gum damage
Avoid smoking and excessive alcohol consumption
Seek immediate dental care if you notice any signs of infection
Do not ignore tooth pain or swelling, as early treatment prevents complications
diseases.description: A dental abscess is a bacterial infection that leads to a collection of pus inside the teeth, gums, or bone surrounding the teeth. It often results from untreated cavities, gum disease, or dental trauma. If left untreated, the infection can spread to other parts of the body, leading to serious complications.
medicines: Antibiotics (e.g., Amoxicillin, Clindamycin, Metronidazole for bacterial infection control)
Pain relievers (e.g., Ibuprofen, Acetaminophen for pain management)
Antiseptic mouthwashes (e.g., Chlorhexidine to reduce bacterial growth)
Dental procedures (e.g., root canal therapy, tooth extraction, or incision and drainage for severe cases)

diseases.name: Coma
symptoms: Unconsciousness lasting for an extended period
No response to external stimuli (pain, sound, or light)
Closed eyes with no voluntary movement
Loss of reflexes in severe cases
precautions: Seek immediate medical attention if a person shows signs of coma
Monitor vital signs and keep the airway open
Prevent head injuries by wearing protective gear (e.g., helmets, seatbelts)
Manage chronic conditions such as diabetes, high blood pressure, and infections
